body:
@hallas  - The idea here is to increase visibility of and divert traffic to interactive spaces that are better suited to supporting new users. While I do really like the awesome-go.com collection, it does serve a different purpose, IMO.

@adg: My preference would be to structure the offerings, perhaps along these lines. But I do think that front-page, header links to SO and /r/reddit would be even more helpful.

* New and need help?
    * Check Stack Overflow first
    * Need quick help or advice on a specific problem, gophers.slack.com
    * If you prefer IRC, there is also #go-nuts.
* Want to stay informed?
    * Keep an eye on /r/golang
    * Checkout Go on G+
    * Follow the @ golang account on Twitter, and keep an eye on the #golang tag
* Mailing lists frequented by the Go community:
    * golang-nuts@ for general discussion about Go (very high traffic)
    * golang-announce@ for just major announcements (very low traffic)
    * golang-dev@ if you're interested in contributing to the Go project (medium traffic)
* Where do I go next?
    * The Go Wiki
    * Awesome-go.com
